newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asia Naphtha/Mogas - Steady despite high stocks.
newsitem.headline: Asia Naphtha/Mogas - Steady despite high stocks.

text.p: The light distillates were steady to firm on Thursday despite ample supplies, traders said.

Weekly stocks in Singapore were only a shade lower with a 60,000-barrel draw, keeping stocks at a two-year high of 7.543 million barrels for the week ending April 23, Singapore's Trade Development Board (TDB) statistics showed on.
Light distillate comprise gasoline, reformate and naphtha.
The region was well-supplied with naphtha with Indonesian cargoes also on offer, as well as fresh export tenders from India.
Indonesia's state oil company, Pertamina announced the loading schedule for its May allocation of 880,000 barrels of naphtha, the same as in April.

European major British Petroleum has been allocated two heavy naphtha cargoes from Balikpapan, in Kalimantan lifting May 11-13 and May 20-30 and one full range paraffinic naphtha cargo from Cilacap in Java, lifting May 25-27.
The second Cilacap cargo, lifting May 10-12, will be absorbed domestically by Indonesian petrochemical firm PT Chandra Asri.

State-owned Indian Oil Corp issued two tenders to sell 27,000 tonnes of high aromatic naphtha (HAN) lifting May 17-19 and 30,000 tonnes of low aromatic naphtha (LAN) lifting May 11-13, both from Madras on the east coast.
The LAN tender closes April 30 and the HAN tender on May 8.
Gasoline was also well-supplied with four to five South Korean cargoes heard available for lifting in May.
Talk on the Singapore fob market was thin with only a bid for 50,000-barrels of May 95-octane heard at $24.10 per barrel and a 92-octane cargo was offered at $23.80.
On Wednesday, 97-octane lifting mid-May was traded at $24.50 per barrel, and the 92-octane grade bid at $23.85.
(Prices are in dollars per barrel)
MTH FOB SIN BUY/SELL PREV BUY/SELL
MAY NAPHTHA SWAPS 21.40/21.50 21.15/21.40
JUN NAPHTHA SWAPS 21.40/21.50 21.20/21.40
APR GASOLINE SWAPS - - -/- - - - - -/- - -
-- Singapore Newsroom (+65-870 3086)
